The much-anticipated Karwa Chauth moon often graces the sky later in the evening. This timing isn't random but stems from the moon's orbital path, its celestial position, and Earth's geographical alignment.
Karwa Chauth occurs on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the moon's waning phase (Krishna Paksha). Since it's just four days after the full moon, moonrise happens later in the evening.
The moon appears about 50 minutes later each day. By the fourth waning night, this delay grows, making moonrise much later than it was on the full moon night.
Your exact spot on Earth—your latitude and longitude—sets the precise time the moon rises. This explains why times vary between locations.
